text: that's one corner right up there the
property and then there's a fence that
goes down through there and that's the
other corner Dan Duvall owns a 72 acre
ranch at the very edge of the coastal
California city of San Luis Obispo San
Luis Obispo is halfway between Los
Angeles and San Francisco it's right on
the coast it's God's country it's
paradise it's beautiful he has some
livestock geese chickens and about 30
head of cattle but that's where the
bucolic ideal of a California ranch and
Duvall's reality part ways no they would
like for me to have black cows white
fences and green pasture and just give
up on my other endeavors Duvall's main
endeavor is sunny acres a ramshackle
collection of tents trailers and
illegally built structures which he
offers to the homeless but have also put
him at odds with his neighbors and
county officials homeless problem is a
big problem in this country right now
Duvall says he's uniquely positioned to
help the homeless having faced addiction
and despair himself name's Dan I'm an
addict alcoholic thank you he attends
weekly substance abuse meetings with the
30 or so people who live on his ranch I
had developed a quite a drinking
schedule alcohol a lot of Hell raisin
racing motorcycles boats dune buggies a
bad accident left him with a limp and
other problems I was hopelessly addicted
to painkillers Duvall kicked his
drinking in pill habit years ago and now
he wants to help other struggling people
my theory or what I want a show can be
done is that you can take people out of
the creek and show them how to help
themselves at no cost to the taxpayers
these people are can be relatively
self-sustaining that's the goal of Sunny
Acres this is a bypass line up here this
is your I just have ideas it's like
these old tractors that I have to me
it's inspiring to get an old tractor
that's totally washed up and bring it
back from nothing and do something with
it
you want to crank it and work with your
fuel system until you get filled
Duvall has a similar view on people they
can be rebuilt if given the chance he
says which is why everyone staying here
has to volunteer around the ranch those
who can't afford his $300 per month rent
work they sell produce in the warmer
months firewood in the winter and of
course they help fix up old tractors
this works great I've been here for
almost five months now been clean every
step of the way and dance is great you
know he's always there for us always has
his door open you know forever need
anything and he's willing to teaches and
help us you know get back into the
workforce and getting you know get our
life straight some see Duvall as a saint
who gives struggling people a second
chance
others think he's a dangerous nuisance
dead cow he'd left his kind of head down
laying sideways right there for all the
neighborhood to see left it there for
months and months as it bloated
Christine Mulholland a former San Luis
Obispo City Council member lives
directly adjacent to mr. Duvall's ranch
she says his heart may be in the right
place but that he's going about the
problem in the wrong way no matter how
good his intentions might be there's no
way he can help all the homeless he has
a Greek ultras own land it's not zoned
for group housing it's not zoned for
recovery programs Duvall's recovery
program has repeatedly run afoul of
County laws from storing too many
rusting vehicles to building an illegal
three-story dormitory and a collection
of wooden sheds on his land oh it's all
I've tried to get as some legal housing
get a permit to build some legal housing
here and I know their zoning problems I
know theirs but it's not impossible
folks
County officials shuttered his barn
dormitory last year and have condemned
the sheds in defiance Duvall continues
to take people in arguing that Sunny
Acres fills a gap as the county's
resources are stretched by a growing
homeless population yes they've got a
program that they pour millions of
dollars into but they they can't take
of all the people they just disregard
the rest of them and too many tenants
Duvall's ranch warts and all he's a
haven and a step on the road to recovery
here at the Duvall ranch Dan has given
me everything that I was looking for
work a shelter a place to cook I'm over
30 days sober now first time in shoot
long time long time of years many years
that I can say that I feel good I feel
healthy I feel strong
